title: SDS410: Capstone in SDS
text:
Today

Attempt 2: Knit term paper document. If you were NOT able to knit term_paper.Rmd last lecture:

Install the tinytex package
Run tinytex::install_tinytex(). If you get a warning that “a LaTeX distribution may have existed in the system.” say yes anyways.
Open and close RStudio
Try knitting term_paper/term_paper.Rmd again. If you get a warning that you need to run tinytex::reinstall_tinytex(), do so.
If are now able to knit, update your answer in the Roster Google Sheet -> Individuals tab
If you were NOT able to knit the document, take a screenshot of your error message, go to Slack #general and reply to the thread with it.

New tab on top-left of webpage Sprints

Intermediate GitHub: Advanced collaboration (beyond just pushes, pulls, and commits).

GitHub repo branches: master (default) and new branches
When to commit/push changes directly to master versus creating a branch
What’s the difference between creating a branch versus a fork?
Pull requests: merge changes into other branches

See screencasts tab on top-right of this page for demos on how to do this.

title: Sprints
text:
Overview
Three times a semester there will be a day where a sprint demo and sprint retrospective is held (see calendar for exact dates). This is an opportunity for a getting feedback and conducting a blameless postmortem on both:

The technical component of the project
The group dynamics component of the project




Agendas
Here are the agendas for the 3 sprints demos/retrospectives this semester:

Agenda for Sprint #1 demo & retrospective
Agenda for Sprint #2 demo & retrospective
Agenda for Sprint #3 demo & retrospective




Sprint demos x3
Sprint demos provide a mechanism for the team to get feedback on work in progress in regular intervals. Sprint demos should (where in this case the stakeholder is just Prof. Kim):

demonstrate the current working behavior of any data science products
articulate to stakeholders what was accomplished and what was not during the sprint
receive feedback from stakeholders
suggest a path forward during the next sprint

Format:

No required format, just whatever you think is best for communication. Previously, some groups were able to just show and narrate when they had in RStudio or a Jupyter Notebook, others made slides that weren’t perfectly polished.
Each group has limited time so use your time wisely.




Sprint retrospectives x3
Sprint retrospectives provide a mechanism for continually improving the working relationship among your team. Themes to be discussed include, but are not limited to:

What went well in the sprint? (“I like…”)
What didn’t go well in the sprint (“I don’t like…”)
What could be improved? (“I wish…”)
What will we commit to improve in the next Sprint? (“What if…”)
How can Albert and Megan help you?

After your retrospective session with Megan Lyster, you will return to your Group Norms Google Doc, go to the appropriate sprint number section, and write a retrospective based on the prompts given in the agenda above.



Project presentations
At the end of the semester A presentation will be given by students to all sponsors, stakeholders, and the professor.
